Quantum mechanics is a highly successful theory that has been very influential in physics and mathematics. It has also been the subject of intense philosophical scrutiny. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the mathematical structure of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This is a significant advance over previous attempts to characterize quantum theory, which have presupposed some form of analysis. The categorical characterization is also more general than previous ones, in that it applies to a much larger class of theories.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts, including humans. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune system is one of the main reasons for the high mortality of many viral diseases. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of interferon (IFN). Our results provide a mechanism of action for the anti-IFN activity of the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6, which is a key player in the evasion of the host antiviral response. Our findings may help to develop new strategies to combat the ongoing pandemic. (Show more)

Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. How Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. The world will need to produce more food to feed a projected 10 billion people by the middle of the 21st century. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase in all major maize-producing and -exporting countries, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. This study also shows that the instability of global maize production will increase, and the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices will increase. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, despite decades of research, the extent to which different species consume the same food plants is largely unknown. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic LMH in semiarid African savanna. Our results show that, even among closely related species, diet composition differs, and that diet overlap is greatest between species that are similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These findings suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the need for more comprehensive, species-level diet analyses to understand the role of LMH in African savanna ecosystems.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off or closed, and that the majority of businesses expect to close within the next 3 mo. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many businesses expect to access the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible signs of the environmental impact of human activities. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than the 1.15 million tons per year estimated by the United Nations Environment Programme. This discrepancy is due to the selective removal of the smaller particles by a combination of processes, including nano-fragmentation, that are still poorly understood. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris, which is of fundamental importance to assess the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in science. The solar system is thought to have formed from the gravitational collapse of a molecular cloud. However, the formation of the solar system is not a closed system, but is connected to the interstellar medium. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is much younger than the formation of the solar system. This indicates that the solar system is not the only system in the universe.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased by a factor of 5.5. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased by a fifth since 1950, and the global abundance of fish has declined by a third. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to produce offspring is a fundamental characteristic of all animals. In this study, we show that the ability to produce offspring is also a highly conserved trait across species. We find that the ability to produce offspring is correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is not only available to the mother, but also to the offspring. We show that the amount of energy available to the offspring is also correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This suggests that the amount of energy available to the offspring is a limiting factor on the amount of energy available to the mother. This study suggests that the amount of energy available to the mother is a fundamental constraint on the number of offspring that can be produced. This is a fundamental insight into the evolution of reproduction.

Alpha-synuclein (α-syn) is a protein that is implicated in the pathogenesis of several neurodegenerative disorders. In multiple system atrophy (MSA), α-syn accumulates in oligodendrocytes, leading to their death. In this study, we show that the inflammatory protease caspase-1, which is activated in MSA, is able to cleave the C terminus of α-syn, leading to its oligomerization and toxicity. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to preserve their function in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a potential therapeutic for MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept of the potential of VX-765 to slow down the progression of MSA. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is critical for controlling the function of the endothelium, but the nature of the network is poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. The findings provide a framework for understanding the structure and function of the endothelial network. This framework can be applied to other cell types and networks in the body. The findings also provide a model for the design of networks in other biological systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health agencies and researchers. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers, health agencies, and the public.

This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. A Threonine to Alanine substitution at this position was studied in three representative members of the K+-channel family. Interestingly, all of the mutant channels exhibited lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of their allosteric coupling (i.e., closing of the activation gate collapses the channel’s selectivity filter). Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the natural products that are produced by the gut microbiome are poorly characterized. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the natural products of anaerobic fungi that are found in the digestive tracts of herbivores. The results of this study provide a foundation for the discovery of natural products that could be used for the treatment of human disease.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is still unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and the structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases that can seamlessly collaborate to produce complex responses. The synthesized structures are digitally designed and manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be extended to design structures with different materials and structures to achieve complex responses, which can be applied to a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin gene expression pattern is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and microRNAs. Here we show that the mRNA-binding protein insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the developing human fetus and is down-regulated in the adult. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells. IGF2BP1 silencing results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This mechanism involves sustained activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, which, in turn, promotes sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-mediated lipogenesis and ferroptosis resistance. This mechanism can be overcome by targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, and the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings may lead to the development of new therapies for cancer patients. (Show more)

Hypertension is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, and the treatment of hypertension is a major public health issue. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are associated with a higher risk of heart failure than other antihypertensive drugs. Our study shows that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in hypertension and for the development of new drugs for treating hypertension. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with older forests, but the decline of older forests accelerated after the plan was repealed. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of early-seral bird populations, which continue to decline on federal land. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and the search for new compounds is still ongoing. In this work, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the physicochemical properties of the compounds, their binding affinity to the ribosome, and their solubility. The best candidates were tested in vitro and in vivo, and the best compound was found to be active against several antibiotic-resistant strains. The approach presented here can be used to design new antibiotics, and it can be extended to other areas of drug development.

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The evolution of the African Rift System is a key process in the formation of the world’s largest lake, Lake Malawi, and the surrounding landscape. This study presents a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability in the tropics, which is critical for the understanding of the evolution of the lake and its ecosystem. The results show that the lake has been highly sensitive to changes in the climate system, and that the lake level has been controlled by a combination of local and global climate forcing. The study also provides evidence for a shift in the climate system at the MPT, which is consistent with far-field climate forcing, and that the climate system has been highly variable in the tropics over the last 1.3 My. This variability has had a profound influence on the evolution of the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of these devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) for 1 h before bedtime suppresses melatonin, reduces evening sleepiness, and phase-delays the circadian clock, compared with reading a printed book. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Earth sciences, but the cause of this cooling is still debated. One of the most popular hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the sediments and magnetic grains/microspherules from the YDB sites in the United States and Belgium are consistent with a terrestrial origin. The YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been the subject of intense investigation. However, the specific contribution of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the periphery and the central nervous system.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this order remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships, and we found that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. Moreover, corresponding (Jurassic) diversification rate increases suggest that these novel genes triggered adaptive radiations that resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species. We propose that PCWDEs enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for other protein molecules, such as vaccines and other therapeutics. Our work also provides a framework for the rapid optimization of other protein molecules in response to emerging variants. This will be critical for the development of effective antiviral and therapeutic strategies against SARS-CoV-2.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to popular belief, population size does not enhance CCE. Instead, it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results suggest that it is not the size of the population that matters, but the diversity of the population. This is an important finding for the study of CCE, as it suggests that the size of the population is not a necessary condition for the emergence of CCE.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE ε4 allele. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. We found that APOE is important for the function of astrocytes, which are highly phagocytic and participate in normal synapse pruning and turnover. APOE is also important for the rate of complement-mediated neurodegeneration of senescent synapses. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes and suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with a higher rate of neurodegeneration in AD patients. These studies also provide a potential mechanism for the beneficial effect of the APOE ε2 allele on AD risk.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere that is 2,356 km in diameter and has a density of 12.0–12.9 g/cm3. It is the only solid sphere in the universe. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory for studying the physics and chemistry of the Earth's interior. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the stable, hexagonal close-packed phase of iron, which is the main component of the inner core, has not been well understood. We demonstrate that the nucleation of the stable phase is not the first step of the inner core formation, but rather the bcc phase, which is metastable, has a much higher nucleation rate than does the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the brain effects of marijuana are not well understood, the drug is known to increase the activity of the brain’s reward system, the nucleus accumbens. Here, we show that the brain’s response to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is reduced in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction. These findings suggest that the reduced brain DA responses in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human skill, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for language processing are the focus of intense investigation. Here, we show that the most accurate artificial neural networks for predicting the next word in a sentence are also the most accurate models of the brain’s neural responses to those sentences in the human brain. These models are also highly predictive of how well the networks fit a challenging language task. These results provide computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms. They also suggest that the brain may usefully be viewed as a large-scale predictive-processing machine. Finally, the models’ high predictive accuracy suggests that the brain’s language processing system may be well-suited to be simulated by artificial neural networks.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful paradigm in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a general property of machine learning, but rather a property of a specific class of problems. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This result implies a classification theory of stability of NNs, which can be used to design algorithms for stable NNs. We introduce a new class of NNs, called fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we prove and numerically verify to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This result is a step toward the development of stable deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the spread of misinformation, and the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 10 y. It shows that the study’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time, and that the study’s conclusion was not questioned. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the nerve-damaging disease leprosy, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the non-neuromuscular disease lepromatous leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they are still able to cause disease, and that they have not lost the ability to cause disease.

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources for quantum information processing and quantum communication. They are also the two main resources for the emergence of thermodynamics. However, the relation between them is still a matter of debate. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of a generic quantum system, which is isolated from the outside world, is completely determined by the dynamics of its entropy. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we find a perfect agreement with the numerical data.

The development of a safe and effective vaccine against SARS-CoV-2 is of utmost importance to combat the COVID-19 pandemic. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on a segment of the viral spike protein, which was codon-pair deoptimized to reduce the viral fitness. The vaccine strain was further modified by deleting the furin cleavage site from the spike protein. The resulting vaccine is highly attenuated, yet still infects cells and generates neutralizing antibodies. In hamsters, the vaccine protects against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. The vaccine is easy to manufacture, can be stored at 2–8 °C, and can be administered intranasally. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but this is not the case in the past. We present a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector, which was common in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries). Our model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. This suggests that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. Our results have implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of research in the field of comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the number of neurons, has been largely ignored. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is as important as the evolution of brain size for understanding the rise of complex cognition. We show that the evolution of brain power is not only driven by the evolution of brain size but also by the evolution of the number of neurons per cell. This study provides a more comprehensive picture of the evolution of brain power and will help to understand the evolution of animal intelligence.

Cancer is a complex disease, and the identification of molecular targets that can be used to treat it is a difficult task. In this study, we have identified a role for TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) in the regulation of metabolism and cell invasiveness in cancer cells. These findings suggest that TRAP1 may be a potential target for the treatment of cancer.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in the disassembly of actin filaments. It does so by binding to the filament and inducing its depolymerization. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we monitor and quantify the action of ADF in different mechanical situations by using single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on ADF binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF binding. We find that this ADF-induced torque does not hinder ADF binding, but dramatically enhances severing. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose, a common carbohydrate found in many foods and beverages. This study shows that the ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of action of common sweeteners and may help to explain the increased prevalence of obesity in the United States and other countries. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a new approach to study the history of Madagascar, and it can be used to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. It also provides a new perspective on the history of human migrations in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a large-scale, real-world demonstration of emotional contagion, and it suggests that people are influenced by the emotions of others even when they are not in the same physical space. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, as well as for our understanding of the role of social networks in the spread of emotions. They also have implications for our understanding of the role of social networks in the spread of emotions.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are modified in a variety of ways that can have important functional consequences. In this work, we show that the most common mRNA modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest effect on the translation of the mRNA. We also show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can increase the rate of protein synthesis. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can have a modest effect on the translation of the mRNA.

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. This is the first study to our knowledge to show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. This finding has implications for the promotion of healthy aging and well-being in older age.

The evolution of body size is a central question in biology. Here, we show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. This study demonstrates that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype of rhinovirus is, in part, due to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and antiviral therapies.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the physical and chemical conditions in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment to the surface, which in turn can stimulate additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is unique to Pseudomonas aeruginosa and may be a general mechanism for bacteria to sense their environment.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the quality of surface water is still poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide contamination of surface water and its impact on the biological integrity of aquatic ecosystems. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the emergence of new variants has raised concerns about the persistence of the virus in animal reservoirs. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, and the identification of multiple lineages of the virus in both deer and humans. Our findings suggest that the virus is likely to persist in deer, and that the risk of spillover into humans is high. These discoveries have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and for the development of strategies to mitigate the risk of spillover into humans.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of this problem, the impacts of large dams, and the solutions that are needed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. However, the immune system is also implicated in AD pathogenesis, and the mechanisms by which it contributes to the disease are not well understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, are capable of producing a variety of potent immune factors, both at the transcript and protein levels. We also demonstrate that the accumulation of soluble Aβ in the brain is sufficient to trigger an inflammatory response in neurons, which may precede the formation of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. These findings provide insight into the complex interplay between the immune system and the neurons in AD, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is a story of a species that was first used for symbolic and social purposes, and only later, after it was acclimatized in the Mediterranean region, was it adopted for economic purposes. This study shows that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens dates to the Hellenistic period, some 2,000 y ago.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are not known for most proteins. This is a problem of fundamental importance in biology, and it is also of great practical importance in the development of new drugs. The study of the folding of a single protein, maltose binding protein, has been a model system for the study of protein folding for more than 25 y. This paper describes a detailed study of the folding of maltose binding protein, which is a large protein (370 residues) that is widely used as a model protein. The results are of fundamental importance for the study of protein folding, and they are also of practical importance for the development of new drugs.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are often described as alarmones because their cellular concentration increases in response to stress, have recently been shown to function in bacteria as precursors to nucleoside tetraphosphate (Np4) RNA caps. In this study, we show that, in Escherichia coli experiencing disulfide stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no effective treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is an effective strategy to increase arginine availability and restore T cell function and proliferation in a mouse model of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, in which a system evolves in time in such a way that the rate of change of the system’s energy is nearly constant. This paper is about a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum devices. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its properties are difficult to control. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly through strain engineering, and that the bandgap can be tuned reversibly through strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. This work provides a new route to control the properties of diamond, and opens up new opportunities for applications.

The study of the structure and function of plant immune peptides is still in its infancy. This study provides a structural and functional insight into the antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. The structure of the peptide was solved by NMR spectroscopy, and it was shown to be a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The antifungal activity of the peptide was attributed to its ability to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in germlings, followed by penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli. The study provides a structural and functional insight into the antifungal activity of a unique NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula. This work also paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the life history of sperm is intimately linked to the female reproductive tract. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the proteome of sperm, and that these contributions are enriched for processes associated with energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the life history of sperm and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–female reproductive tract interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular hand-off between males and females.

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to the glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) receptor on the surface of platelets. The binding reaction is triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. We show that force application switches VWF from a low-force to a high-force state, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of VWF function. The mechanism also provides a way to control the binding of other proteins to receptors on the surface of cells.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. We find that viruses are associated with many different diseases, and that the virome is more complex than the bacteriome. This study is a major step forward in the study of the human microbiome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a complex process that is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. This study introduces a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The HSRL was used to conduct continuous observations of aerosols and clouds over Beijing, China, to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The temperature of the early Earth has been a topic of intense debate. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of reconstructed ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the targets of drugs and toxins. Ion channels are classified into three types based on their structure and function. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a type-3 channel that is normally open and inactivated slowly. We found that the BK channel has two pore gates, one for fast activation/deactivation and the other for slow inactivation/recovery. We also found that the BK channel’s inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because BK channel inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of inactivation. These findings provide a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. They also provide a theoretical basis for the development of drugs and toxins that target ion channels. Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a complex process, and the mechanisms by which the parasite achieves entry are still not fully understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC, and this interaction alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite is not simply pushing against the RBC, but rather is working with the RBC to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, and it suggests that the malaria parasite is not simply pushing against the RBC, but rather is working with the RBC to facilitate entry. It is a promising material for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum devices. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its properties are difficult to control. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans and animals. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While the impact of low humidity on viral transmission has been well-established, the impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in caspase-1/11, an enzyme involved in the antiviral response. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the mechanisms of influenza-induced lung injury and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza infection. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree of nested phrases. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this claim is limited. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a model of phrase construction, in which each word is merged into a phrase, and the brain’s activity increases with the number of words in the phrase. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be important for understanding the brain’s processing of spoken and written language, as well as the development of language in children.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in a wide variety of biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin, which is essential for the proper functioning of the Wnt signaling pathway. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanism of redundant genes and may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The brain is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the function of any one part without considering the rest of the system. This study provides a comprehensive characterization of a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a key technology for sustainable food production. Here, we have developed a system for the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal plant, using a bacterial signal to regulate the expression of genes controlling nitrogen metabolism and the nitrogenase enzyme. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to control the nitrogen cycle in agriculture, and could also be applied to other organisms, such as cyanobacteria, which fix N2 in the environment.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a global concern. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, the Amazon is still losing forest at an alarming rate. We study a community-based monitoring program that was designed to reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their bodies to sense the world around them, but some animals, such as spiders, can sense the world without a body. This study shows that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can sense the world without a body, and that it can do so by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, and the spider can localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave by sensing the motion of the web. The spider can also increase its hearing surface area by 10,000 times, and can regularly regenerate and adjust the size of its web to suit its needs. This study provides a unique model for studying extended and regenerative sensing and design of acoustic flow detectors. It also provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing and the body. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global community. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the pandemic. This study describes the design and characterization of a recombinant protein-based vaccine candidate that can be produced at large scale, with the potential to provide a cost-effective solution for the global community.
We report on the identification of a ligand for the ALK/LTK family of receptors, which is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been a constant threat to humanity for millennia. This study provides a comprehensive view of the evolution of plague during its formative years, from the time it emerged from Yersinia pseudotuberculosis to the time it adapted to the flea vector. We show that the emergence of plague was a gradual process, and that the pathogen underwent a series of evolutionary steps before it adapted to the flea vector. This study also reveals the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, a region previously only known to have the other form of plague. These data provide a more complete picture of the early evolution of plague and its adaptation to the flea vector. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols is a major source of SOC loss to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral soil. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon on a global scale and provide a framework for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, and we validated the framework using data from virus discovery and surveillance efforts. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts animals to flowers, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of this reward are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this compound and demonstrate that the same three activities are required for the production of the red pigment in two other plants visited by vertebrates. This work provides a molecular framework for understanding the evolution of this type of adaptation and the mechanisms that underlie the production of this reward.

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of migration and admixture processes. However, the genetic history of the period between the Roman Empire and the Middle Ages is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from southern Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 7th century AD. Our results indicate that the genetic history of this period is more complex than previously thought, and that the genetic landscape of Europe was shaped by a combination of migration and admixture processes. In addition, we identified a number of functional variants that were already at modern-like frequencies in this period. Our results provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during a period of great cultural change. They also highlight the potential of genome sequencing to provide a more complete picture of the history of Europe.

Bats are the natural hosts of coronaviruses, including Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), and are considered the source of MERS-CoV. However, the potential for MERS-CoV to spill over to humans has been a major concern. Here, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, and found that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry. These results suggest that MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has the potential to cause a pandemic. Our findings also suggest that bats may be a reservoir of other emerging coronaviruses that can infect humans. This study provides insights into the molecular basis of MERS-CoV transmission to humans and the origin of other bat coronaviruses. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of host range and cell entry activity of emerging coronaviruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability to rapidly identify the pathogens causing undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for the early detection and response to emerging epidemics. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce Southeast Asia is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied to other resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate the impact of emerging epidemics. (Show more)

The human genome is synthesized in a highly processive manner by the replication machinery. However, when the replication fork stalls, the replication machinery must dissociate from the DNA to allow for the recruitment of other repair and transcription factors. This process is critical for the maintenance of genome integrity and the ability to repair DNA damage. We developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme dissociates from PCNA while replicating DNA and that this process is critical for the maintenance of genome integrity.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA, and the replication of RNA was catalyzed by ribozymes. In this paper, we describe the evolution of a ribozyme that can now replicate RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This is a significant step toward the reconstruction of the RNA world and the origin of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical patients with COVID-19 are analyzed, and the immune characteristics of patients with severe COVID-19 are summarized. The results show that the immune system is in a state of imbalance, and the inflammatory storm is the main cause of death. Tocilizumab, which can reduce the level of IL-6, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical patients with COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but it is also a toxic metal that can cause damage to cells and tissues. The ability of fungi to bind copper and to use this process to control the cellular copper content is a novel finding. This work provides a mechanism for the control of copper homeostasis in fungi and may have implications for the control of copper toxicity in other organisms.

The formation of silica in the martian environment is a key to understanding the origin and evolution of the planet. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary deposit at the base of a high-silica, high-temperature (870 °C) flow in Gale crater, Mars, is a significant finding.

Frost is a major environmental stressor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees, and that the resistance strategies of trees are linked to the rate of change in frost events. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. We found that the development of colitis required the development of Th1-like cells from a subset of Th17 precursors, and that Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings may help to identify targets for the development of novel therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in several genes, but the mechanisms are not understood. We now report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes, which can be expanded in culture and used to study the disease. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This will help in the development of new therapies for ALS. This study also highlights the importance of easy production of induced pluripotent stem cells for disease modeling and drug screening. This method can be applied to other diseases and cell types. (Show more)

The role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts is a rapidly emerging field of study. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis, modifies the microbiota of the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to reduce the ability of the tick to defend against infection and to increase the ability of the pathogen to form biofilms. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an antibacterial protein from an arthropod to more efficiently colonize its vector. This work also provides a framework for understanding the role of the microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful animal lineages, and the study of their evolution has been a major focus of paleontology for more than a century. However, the study of the origins of the modern avian bauplan has been complicated by the limited known diversity of early branching members of the group. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, which adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan.

We show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity of the climate system. This is a significant finding, as it means that the climate system is more sensitive to greenhouse gas concentrations than previously thought.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and the color of an animal can be used to assess its health, identity, and even its species. In this study, we describe a new mechanism for the control of color, which is based on the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is formed when hemoglobin is degraded. Our results provide a molecular explanation for the evolution of green color in vertebrates, and a mechanism for the control of color in animals.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with the maintenance of cancer stem cells, which are responsible for tumor initiation and recurrence. We report that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase, AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is maintained at high levels by ALKBH5, and is required for the maintenance of cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This paper reports the results of a study of 465 parchment samples from 72 pocket Bibles and 293 additional samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, and instead found evidence for the use of several species of mammal. This suggests that the production of ultrafine parchment did not necessarily require the use of abortive or newborn animals.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key control on the timing of ecosystem recovery and the duration of the extinction event. The age model for the extinction is based on a new U-Pb zircon age model for the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China. The age model is based on five volcanic ash beds that are used as a chronostratigraphic marker. The age model provides a precise age for the onset of the extinction and the timing of the carbon cycle reorganization that preceded the onset of extinction. The age model will be used to evaluate the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms and the timing of ecosystem recovery. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a complex disease with a high incidence, and the current treatment is limited. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the maintenance of intestinal homeostasis and the prevention of IBD. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. View Full-Text

The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating variants and is thought to increase infectivity. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutant spike is more flexible and can adopt a range of more open conformations. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase infectivity, but the precise mechanism is unclear.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
