COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that have contributed to the disproportionate burden of COVID-19 in the United States

The chemical properties of an element are the result of the interplay between the electronic structure of the atom and the chemical environment in which it is embedded. The chemical properties of an atom are also the result of the interplay between the electronic structure of the atom and the chemical environment in which it is embedded. In this work, we show that the electronic structure of an atom is the result of the interplay between the electronic structure of the atom and the chemical environment in which it is embedded.

Fire is a key driver of the global carbon cycle, but the effects of climate change on fire activity are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, as caused by socioeconomic development, can have a large impact on fire activity and the carbon cycle. We find that, although uncertainty in projected fire effects is large, changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to better understand the effects of human activities on fire regimes.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic partners is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan to the luminescent symbiont of a squid is precisely timed to maintain the stability of the symbiosis. This glycan is released by the host only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most active, and is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the organ is at its most acidic. This glycan-driven regulation of the symbiosis is likely to be a common mechanism used by animals to control the activities of their associated microbes.

Text data are ubiquitous and have been used to study a wide range of topics. However, the latent structure of text data is often unknown. This makes it difficult to identify patterns of interest, such as the topics that are present in a corpus. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a generative model to infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives of violent deaths, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be used to identify latent patterns in many domains. We believe that this will be a valuable tool for researchers and practitioners.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. View Full-Text

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of the ecosystem. However, they are also a potential source of food for sea stars, which are important predators in the marine food web. We show that a virus is responsible for the mass mortality of asteroids. This is the first report of a virus causing mass mortality of a marine invertebrate.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of new targets for therapy is of great importance. We show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We also show that IL1RAP can be targeted with an antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based therapy in other diseases. This approach could be used to target other proteins expressed on leukemic stem cells, such as CD133, CD44, or CD117. The use of antibodies as a treatment for AML is currently under investigation in clinical trials.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population, and it will be useful for the study of the human history of Madagascar. It will also be a valuable resource for the study of human populations in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for other protein molecules, such as vaccines and other therapeutics. Our work provides a new approach to antibody engineering and may help to accelerate the development of new therapeutics.

Crop experts are the first line of defense for the US agricultural sector, providing information on the status of crops across the country. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily used for quantitative analysis. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which collects this information, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited for quantitative analysis. We also show that the CPC reflects the subjective perception of many surveyors at different locations, and that the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. Finally, we demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert surveys in agricultural monitoring and forecasting. It also provides a valuable resource for the agricultural sector, as well as for researchers and policymakers.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This is a departure from the view that memory is based on sustained, elevated neural activity. Our work provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic information over time, which is a key process in language processing. This work is also relevant to the study of memory in general, as it provides a mechanism for memory that is based on the dynamics of the nervous system.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance for predicting future changes in the carbon cycle. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. We present the results of a global synthesis of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis provides limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrates that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. This information is critical for predicting the future fate of soil carbon in a warmer world.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging problems in biology, because it is difficult to study the process in its entirety. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the process of functional reduction is not a single event, but rather a series of events, each of which is characterized by a burst of gene losses.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark example of the impact of climate change on water security in South Africa and the rest of the world. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This study is of relevance to other regions of the world that are vulnerable to drought, such as the southwestern United States, Australia, and the Middle East. View Full-Text

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” in 1945, was a seminal event in the history of science. The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the only material from the test that survived, is a unique link to the past and a reminder of the future.

(Bacterio)chlorophylls are the light-harvesting pigments of oxygenic photosynthetic organisms. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained a mystery for more than 60 y. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze this reaction, and their role in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that ASK1-dependent glial cell interactions are important in the pathophysiology of EAE, and thus, glial ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new strategies for treating neurodegenerative diseases. The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought years that are also warm has increased substantially. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. This work is based on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that examined the psychophysiological reactions of 1,000 participants to real news video clips. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of store-operated Ca2+ entry, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 are associated with severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which are associated with a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and miosis, and in ORAI1, which is associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome of miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy but without hematological abnormalities. These findings expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated store-operated Ca2+ entry, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates causes the death of vulnerable neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the fusion of lysosomes and the endocytic system, and that the release of aggregates is dependent on the fusion of lysosomes and the endocytic system. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are the only mammals that can live in caves, and they are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and thus requires the maintenance of the one-carbon unit, which is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit-generating enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used it to identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. This vulnerability is rooted in the requirement of cancer cells for the import of glycine, a key amino acid that is generated from the one-carbon unit. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that is rooted in the requirement of cancer cells for the import of glycine. This is a potentially targetable vulnerability of cancer cells.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is not observed in other human tissues, suggesting that the metastable state is a specific feature of motor neurons that is lost in other tissues. This study provides a mechanism for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS and other neurodegenerative diseases. It also suggests that the metastable state may be a general feature of proteins that are prone to aggregation. This may have implications for the design of therapeutic strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be of interest to researchers in many areas, including quantum optics, atom optics, quantum information science, and many-body physics. The results are also expected to be of interest to researchers in the fields of photonics, metamaterials, and plasmonics.
The origin of the flowering plants is a major question in plant evolution. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a new understanding of the origin of the flowering plants.

The study of ancient viruses is hampered by the lack of ancient viral DNA in the archaeological record. Here we present the first ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences, which are dated to the early Holocene. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the recombination event that formed the third B19V genotype occurred at a time when the virus was already widespread. These findings are important for our understanding of the evolution of viruses and the history of human–virus interactions. View Full-Text
We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with the rate of acceleration of the climate system.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically characterized picture of the reaction of the α-aminoacrylate intermediate with indole, a reaction that is the first step in the synthesis of the natural product tryptophanase. This study highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a mechanistic picture of enzyme reactions, and the importance of the chemical information provided by NMR in the interpretation of crystallographic data.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) continues to emerge with a high case fatality rate, stressing the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. We report the results of a study testing the efficacy of remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir was highly effective in preventing the development of clinical disease and in reducing the viral load in the lungs, and was able to prevent the formation of lung lesions. These results support the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic partners is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan to the luminescent symbiont of a squid is critical for the maintenance of the symbiosis. This glycan is released by the host only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most metabolically active, and is catabolized by the symbiont only at night, when the organ is at its most acidic. This glycan-driven regulation of the symbiosis is likely to be a common mechanism used by animals to control the activities of their associated microbiota.

This paper presents a series of experiments that show that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies, the development of effective teacher training, and the design of scalable interventions to reduce suspension rates.

DNA alkylation is one of the major causes of DNA damage and is involved in the development of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions have distinct effects on the efficiency and accuracy of transcription. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered MERS viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis, which is required for virus entry into cells. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and therefore may be a target for developing vaccines and antiviral drugs.

The food system is a major contributor to environmental degradation and is a leading cause of biodiversity loss, water pollution, and greenhouse gas emissions. The food choices of the global population are a key driver of these impacts. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a significant impact on meal selection. This is a significant finding, as increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting is a simple and low-cost intervention that can be implemented in a wide range of settings. The results of this study have implications for the food industry, policymakers, and individuals seeking to reduce their environmental footprint and improve their health. This study also provides evidence of the effectiveness of a simple nudge to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting. This is an important finding, as it demonstrates that simple interventions can be effective in changing behavior and improving population health. The results of this study have implications for the food industry, policymakers, and individuals seeking to reduce their environmental footprint and improve their health.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a breast cancer cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant contribution to the field of cancer biology and drug discovery.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast ballots by mail instead of going to the polls. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout rates. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the COVID-19 disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is proposed to be involved in immune evasion. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for the unique properties of the protein.

Cerebral edema is a life-threatening condition, and the mechanisms underlying its development are not fully understood. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex, which in turn leads to an increase in water influx into the cortex and cerebral edema. These findings provide a mechanism for the development of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. This article is protected by copyright. The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. Although the importance of transcription factors in EC development has been well established, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key transcription factor that induces EC development from both embryonic and adult stem cells. Our study provides a strategy for the generation of functional ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders and the regeneration of organs. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 as a therapeutic tool for the treatment of vascular disorders is also discussed. This study provides a better understanding of the development of vascular ECs and may lead to the development of new therapies for vascular disorders. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a third class of ligand for the receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that the zebrafish homologs of these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized epidermal tissue that is responsible for the coloration of the zebrafish. This discovery provides a link between the ligand class and Ltk and demonstrates that the ligand class is important for the development of iridophores in the zebrafish. This work also provides a model system for the study of the function of the ligand class in other contexts.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Although the role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity has been well established, its function in β-cell is still unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, leading to T2D. These findings provide a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of T2D and may help in the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasionally for severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. This mechanism might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our study provides a molecular understanding of the packaging process of the influenza A virus. This knowledge might be used to develop new strategies to combat influenza. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of a complex interplay between the local hemodynamic environment and the endothelial cells. This study provides evidence that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is a key event in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our findings suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the regulation of vascular homeostasis and atherogenesis. These findings may help to develop a new approach for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been a part of the Earth system for millennia. However, the frequency and extent of wildfire in the United States has increased substantially in recent decades, and is projected to continue to increase in the future. This increase is likely due to a combination of factors, including climate change, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of human-caused wildfires and the need for increased management of these fires to reduce fire risk.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a class of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insects. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are still unknown. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and it should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It also demonstrates the evolutionary adaptation of natural repellents to the arthropod–plant interaction. This study is also a good example of the application of genome sequencing in the study of ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model is able to reproduce the observed dynamics of the disease, and we provide estimates of the parameters of the model. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the dynamics of the disease. The results of this study can be used to guide the development of new strategies to control the disease. Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on the planet, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This shift from nutrient uptake to release by the coral host promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates, leading to the functional loss of the coral–algal symbiosis. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We find that the loss of BMP signaling leads to the activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, which in turn triggers a dysbiotic microbiome and stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors. This study also provides a model for the study of the role of the microbiome in the development of other types of tumors. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. In this study, we found that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 was increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this expression was associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. We also found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most debated topics in the last-glacial history of the planet. Here we show that the start of deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption, which is the first of a series of volcanic eruptions that continued for 192 y.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of fisheries and biodiversity. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human population density and river discharge. We also show that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished, and that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the importance of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our data can be used to improve the management of inland fisheries and to protect the biodiversity of river ecosystems.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Regeneration is a powerful process that can restore function after injury. However, the mechanisms that control regeneration are not well understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular mechanisms that control regeneration in the adult nervous system.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome and is a key target for therapeutic intervention. However, the spatial and temporal patterns of recombination in the genome are not well understood. We use a population of wild plants to map the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the control of cognitive functions. The identification of these networks is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality, positron emission tomography, to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the resting state networks in cerebral blood flow scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant resting state network was deactivated during rest and activation during task performance. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a new approach to the study of the brain organization in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, a 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes is consistent with the view that the 5′ cap is a common feature of all eukaryotic mRNA.

The study of the mechanisms of the metabolic memory phenomenon, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up, has been hampered by the lack of a suitable model. We used a population-based study of people with diabetes to show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also provides a model for the study of the mechanisms of metabolic memory. This model can be used to study the effects of lifestyle interventions and to test the effects of new drugs. It can also be used to study the effects of the environment on the development of diabetes complications.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and has no approved targeted therapy. We show that the tumor suppressor gene, FSIP1, is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells promotes autophagy, which in turn, inhibits the growth of TNBC cells in vitro and in vivo. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 in autophagy and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant proportion of alcohol-dependent subjects, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence, and that it may be a target for the management of this disorder.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma of the fruit. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the contribution of nitrogenous volatiles to the overall flavor of tomato fruit is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase, which catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This study provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor. It also opens the door to the development of new strategies for improving the flavor of tomato fruit. (Show more)

Biodiversity is a key driver of ecosystem functioning, and the loss of biodiversity is one of the most pressing threats to the functioning of Earth’s ecosystems. However, the impacts of biodiversity loss on ecosystem functioning are frequently investigated separately from the impacts of environmental warming. Here we show that the impacts of environmental warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are highly dependent on the thermal tolerance of species. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes increasingly sensitive to changes in species diversity as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, indicating that the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of both biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. This will be critical for predicting the impacts of global warming on the functioning of Earth’s ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for spatial memory and navigation. It is thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, as well as the animal’s position in space, in the form of a map. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a miniaturized, portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings provide a more complete picture of the organization of MEC and may help to elucidate the mechanisms underlying spatial memory and navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the FT gene is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized organization of the dopamine-containing neurons in the ventral tegmental area. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons in the ventral tegmental area form highly unusual arborizations that target clusters of their parent cell bodies and also form specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing system. These findings have implications for our understanding of the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all have a sense of when we are connected to others, and when we are not. But how do we know when two people are connected to each other? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat and are characterized by their unique electrophysiological properties. SANCs are the only cells in the heart that have a high content of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores and are the only cells in the heart that are able to release Ca2+ into the cytoplasm. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study reveals a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the heart and provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmia. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, and its beneficial effects on plant resistance against abiotic and biotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of Si in mediating insect herbivore resistance has not been explored. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may promote insect herbivore resistance by priming JA-mediated defense responses. These findings may provide insights into the underlying mechanisms of Si-mediated insect herbivore resistance and may contribute to the development of sustainable agricultural practices. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex and dynamic system, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The lipidome of macrophages is also affected by the treatment with the drug phenylbutyrate, which is used for the treatment of phenylketonuria. Here we show that phenylbutyrate treatment of macrophages affects the expression of genes involved in ether lipid metabolism, which is a major class of lipid mediators in macrophages. We also show that phenylbutyrate treatment affects the expression of genes involved in the synthesis of tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor essential for the synthesis of many important molecules in macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and ether lipid metabolism are important for the function of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory in the brain. Information is stored in the form of changes in the excitability of neurons. These changes are adaptive, meaning that they are dependent on the current state of the system. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind information over time. This is a significant advance in our understanding of the brain, as it suggests that memory is not a fixed property of the nervous system, but rather a dynamic process that can be modulated by experience. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and medicine for the human race. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of different DNA nanostructures for their ability to internalize into cells of mature plants, deliver siRNAs, and effectively silence a constitutively expressed gene in Nicotiana benthamiana leaves. We show that the internalization efficiency of DNA nanostructures correlates with their respective gene silencing efficiencies but that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the scientific community working on the delivery of biomolecules to plants. It also provides a platform for the development of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and other organisms.

Nutrient inputs to lakes and coastal ecosystems are driven largely by nonpoint sources from surrounding watersheds. However, the role of small watersheds in driving coastal nutrient inputs is poorly understood. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that the 6 largest of 235 tributaries accounted for ∼70% of the daily N and P delivered to Lake Michigan. However, small watersheds exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that small watersheds may play a greater role in fueling coastal algal blooms than previously thought. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal nutrient inputs and the need to expand nutrient management efforts to these areas.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small fraction of the possible chemical states. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that are extremized with respect to the environmental forcing. This finding is of interest in the context of the search for “robust” states in complex systems, as it suggests that the search for such states may be guided by the environment.

This paper provides a detailed description of the results, the raw data related to the results, model code, and data used in the results, along with instructions for how to reproduce the results. The code and data are available on GitHub: https://github.com/s-m-s-m/NMDAR-Ab-paper.git.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in the field of Earth system history. However, the history of C-rich events is poorly understood, in part because of the difficulty in identifying and dating these events. Here, we present a detailed study of a C-rich event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. This study provides a better understanding of the history of abrupt climate change and the role of organic matter in the Earth system.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of deforestation in Indonesia, a country with a high carbon footprint. Certification is the most common tool used by corporations and countries to reduce this impact. However, the impact of certification on deforestation has been unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation from 2001 to 2015. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is a useful tool for reducing deforestation, but it is not a panacea.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the release of proteins from the trans-Golgi network and the formation of the plasma membrane. Dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a key topic in developmental biology. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of sex determination alleles is not a simple process, and that the evolution of sex determination can result in a variety of phenotypes.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are oxidized by reactive oxygen species and photodegraded into reactive intermediates. We show that the intracellular Fe pool is important for the redox cycling of bisretinoids and their photodegradation. This is of particular importance in albino mice, which have reduced Fe levels, and in mice with increased Fe levels, which are a consequence of reduced Fe export. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that Fe chelation may be a useful strategy for the treatment of this disease. (Read more)

Predators are the drivers of many of the processes that shape our planet, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key driver of the evolution of the rest of the community. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it requires the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that this is not the case, and that specialization can be maintained and even be linked to the evolution of new morphological structures. This study contributes to a broader understanding of the evolution of specialization and morphological diversification in predators, and how it has shaped the structure of present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This is an important finding for understanding the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human hand morphology.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and thus requires the maintenance of the one-carbon unit, which is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit-generating enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used it to identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. This vulnerability is rooted in the requirement of cancer cells for the import of glycine, a key amino acid that is generated from the one-carbon unit. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that is rooted in the requirement of cancer cells for the import of glycine. This vulnerability can be exploited to develop a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s access to fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A, and thus can have negative impacts on people’s health. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase access to fruits and vegetables, which can improve people’s diets. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the impacts of deforestation on people’s diets. This approach can be used to understand the impacts of other environmental changes on people’s diets.

The history of modern agriculture is the history of mechanization, with the increase in vehicle capacity leading to higher output of farm machinery. However, the increase in vehicle weight has also led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, with the risk of loss of soil ecological functioning. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction has increased over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity. We also show that the total weight of modern farm vehicles is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the fact that the largest sauropods, the brachiosaurs, had the largest footprints, suggesting that they may have used them to avoid compaction. Our results suggest that the history of modern agriculture is also the history of the evolution of farm vehicles, with the potential to impact the future of agriculture.
